sentences.sentence: Hamas's murderous Oct. 7 attack on Israel shook the entire planet.

The ignominy, the barbarity, the savagery - including slaughtered infants, rape, the murder of entire families and the cold-blooded hunting and shooting of young festival-goers - provoked widespread outcry.Since then, Israel has pursued military operations to neutralize the threat posed by Hamas to its own citizens, halt the rockets that continue to be launched from Gaza against Israeli civilians and free the hostages held by a terrorist organization capable of horrendous atrocities.By doing so, the State of Israel is asserting its legitimate right to defend itself.
Israel's counter-attack has, nevertheless, raised questions about international law.Make no mistake: Israel has every right to defend itself under international law.
In the absence of a Palestinian state, Hamas is the entity that controls Gaza, and it is directly responsible for the atrocities of Oct. 7.

Israel has not only a right but an obligation to act in self-defence against Hamas.In addition to the codified right to self-defence set out in Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, there is also a customary interpretation of this right from which three criteria emerge for the use of force in self-defence to be deemed legal: the action of self-defence must be immediate, necessary and proportional to an armed attack.Since Oct. 7, Israeli citizens have been living in constant terror of missiles raining down from above, because Hamas has continued its attacks since that dark day, constantly bombarding Israeli towns and villages with rockets from Gaza.

It's an untenable situation that cannot be tolerated by any responsible nation.Of all the accusations levelled against the Jewish state, the most often cited is the supposed disproportionality of Israel's response to these unprecedented attacks by Hamas.International humanitarian law seeks to limit the worst effects of armed conflict, in order to protect civilians from them.

According to the principle of proportionality, "Launching an attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated, is prohibited.

"Loss of non-combatant life remains a reality of armed conflict, but it must be risked only when strictly necessary?- such as when the undesired, but often inevitable, loss of civilian life occurs following the targeting of a highly strategic military location.Proportionality does not require that the damage caused to legitimate military targets be the same on both sides.

It simply requires that the damage caused to civilians should not be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage that's reasonably anticipated from an action.Israel's military objective of eliminating Hamas is clearly legitimate.
Any action taken to this end must be measured in terms of losses and impact.This reality does not mean that Israel is not obligated to do everything in its power to minimize casualties.

It must continue to do so despite Hamas's inhumane practice of using Palestinian civilians as human shields - which is a war crime - and the terrorists' unrelenting and indiscriminate targeting Israeli civilians - another war crime.Israeli casualties since Oct. 7 number in the thousands: 1,400 people murdered, more than 6,000 injured and 242 hostages - including 30 children - remain in the hands of Hamas.
Not since the Holocaust have we witnessed so many Jews killed in a single day.The defence of its citizens is Israel's primary responsibility.

A false interpretation of international law denying Israel's right to self-defence must be denounced in the strongest possible terms.National PostRichard Marceau is vice-president and general counsel of the Centre for Israel and Jewish Affairs (CIJA), a former member of Parliament and a member of the Quebec and Ontario bars.

Emmanuelle Amar is a lawyer with a master's degree in international law and director of public policy and research (Quebec) at CIJA.Joe Oliver: No, Israel's military response does not need to be 'proportionate'(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/no-israels-military-response-does-not-need-to-be-proportionate)John Robson: Polite antisemitism on full display from international law 'experts' at uOttawa(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/polite-antisemitism-on-full-display-from-international-law-experts-at-uottawa) !

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
